Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2012 03:37PM marilyn113 wrote: Two weeks after I completed radiation (9 days ago), I got a very itchy, red, bumpy rash on my stomach below the radiated breast.  It spread to the other side of my stomach, then the inside of my arms and my chest.  Oddly, hardly any of it is on my breasts.  My dermatologist wasn't sure what it was either and gave me some steroid cream (two days ago).  She called it "radiation induced inflammatory rash".  I sure hope it goes away soon!
Posts.Title: Weird Skin Reaction Post-Radiation Jo_Ann_K LindaSuz

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2012 04:18PM marilyn113 wrote: Yes this is common for fibrocystic breasts.  Try Vitamin E.  It can help with breast tenderness.  www.vitaminsect.com/effects-of...

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 05:55PM marilyn113 wrote: I'm getting very close to my 8/1 surgery and I'm pretty calm.  It will be kind of like having a baby.  There will be pain, but good drugs.  There will be sleepless nights, but no screaming kid.  Six months from now, it won't matter whether it took 3 weeks to heal or 6, and I will have reduced my recurrence risk to almost nothing. I got through radiation, I'll get through this.

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2012 08:36AM marilyn113 wrote: I'm not sure which is worse, having to wait weeks/months for surgery or having it happen so fast you don't have time to process what you're going through!  It's hard either way.  Try to do what you can to reduce stress: meditation, medication, yoga, massage, rant on these forums, have a good cry, pray, etc.  Women are strong; most of us have had babies and I can now say that this is way easier.  You will get through this and will have an appreciation for life that many don't. Hugs to all of you!

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 03:07PM marilyn113 wrote: I was diagnosed almost one year ago (9/6) and had my BMX exactly a month ago.  After 4 surgeries and 5 weeks of radiation this past year, I'm ready to move on with my life...once the fatigue finally goes away! My hubby and I are celebrating by going to Ireland in October.  I went to Europe after college in '81 but haven't been to Ireland.  DH has never been outside US and Canada.  He also has a big fear of flying so will get him some Xanax to help with that.  I'm very grateful he has agreed to go. Hope you are all doing well, or at least seeing progress each day.  We should still be looking toward 6 months from now when this will be a distant memory.
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 07:01PM marilyn113 wrote: Hi Ladies.  I'm having a BMX (no recon) on 8/1 and I'm also starting to get nervous.  Just ordered some items from Amazon.  A stool for getting in and out of bed (my bed is high) and a knee support.  i never sleep on my back, so that worries me.  I hope I can get some sleep without too much pain in my neck or back. I also had LCIS, plus DCIS, ADH and a small IDC tumor.  After completing radiation in Jan, I was totally stressed, worrying how they would be able to find a recurrence in my very dense breasts.  I decided I couldn't live with that fear, so almost one year after the lumpectomy that found DCIS and (at that time) "possible" LCIS, I'm getting the ticking time bombs removed.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 10:58PM marilyn113 wrote: My cancer was found with a surgical biopsy.  The margins around the DCIS were clear but <1mm so they did a re-excision.  That surgery found a small amount of invasive cancer.  If they hadn't gone back in because the cancer didn't reach the margins, I would not know the cancer was invasive.  So I think there needs to be some minimum amount of clear margins.

Posts.Title: Hope for Dense Breasts Shanagirl Shanagirl

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2012 02:57PM marilyn113 wrote: Kaara - I have similar diagnosis as you.  Internal therapy was not an option for me due to my age (too young at 52).  I was terrified of radiation but couldn't ignore the significant reduction in recurrence.  I've had 22 out of 25 rads and it has been easy.  (They decided I didn't need the boosts.)  I can't believe I'm done this week already.  My breast is pink and itches slightly, but no blistering or peeling.  I also haven't had the fatigue I feared.  I'm still working and wearing a bra to work.  I see women on this site that originally had stage 1 and had a recurrence at stage 4.  I want to do everything in my power to prevent that.   Skipping radiation now could result in a mx, chemo AND rads in the future.
Posts.Title: Radiation Therapy for early stage Kaara mimikitty

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2012 01:14PM marilyn113 wrote: I have had 17 out of 30 rads.  I was VERY nervous to start like many of you.  Until the last couple of days, it has been very easy.  The mapping was much quicker than I thought.  The tats were painful for me though very quick.  Each treatment takes less than 5 minutes including getting me in position.  The machine zaps about 12 seconds from one side of the breast and 18 from the other side where the cancer was located.  The worst part for me is that the waiting room is co-ed.  I seem to see mostly men waiting plus there's a convict that comes in at that time.  Makes me self conscious sitting there and walking around in my gown.  The last four days I've had fatigue.  I worked 1/2 days on Wed and Thu and not at all on Fri.  Some people could probably work through it, but i don't like working when my productivity is low and I'm out of it.  Also, I've had fibromyalgia for 20 years and expected that it would make the fatigue worse, but don't think it has.  My skin is pink but holding up.  I've been using aloe after tx and My Girls cream at bedtime.  The RO had me start using 1% OTC steroid cream 2 x a day this week.  Good luck to all of you.  I think you will find the first 3 weeks to be a breeze.  I can't vouch for after that yet.
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 01:43PM marilyn113 wrote: Mine didn't show on Mammo or US.  Had surgical biopsy to remove cysts that kept coming back and they found DCIS.  Then had MRI which showed two areas of concern.  Two radiologists, one at a major cancer center, did US and declared those to be harmless cysts.  However, re-excision found more DCIS and a .8 CM area of IDC.  I have very dense breasts.
Posts.Title: Mammogram - Just Curious mingiemoo mingiemoo

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 04:36PM marilyn113 wrote: drjanet - mingimoo was diagnosed in 2009 so her doctor may do an MRI every year to watch for recurrence.  Each test gives different info.  They are probably trying to determine if a biopsy is needed and, if so, what type to do.  It's hard not to panic, but 80% of lumps turn out to be nothing;
Posts.Title: Mammogram - Just Curious mingiemoo mingiemoo

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 07:13PM marilyn113 wrote: Found out today that I won't be having boosts so I get done next Wednesday, a week earlier than I thought.  Yeah!!  After 18 rads I have no pain, a little bit of itching and I'm still wearing a bra to work.  My breast is quite pink, but it doesn't hurt like a sunburn. Kayce234 - I only have 3 tats, one between the breasts and one on each side of my torso.  After I got them I called my son (age 23 with a number of tattoos) and said "Guess what?  I got tattooed." He was pretty shocked until I told him why.  I got a kick out of that!
